title: 111_hr1444
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Commission on Civic Service Act". Congress finds that national service and volunteerism are essential for strengthening the social fabric of the United States and creating a more engaged civic society. Despite declines in civic health, youth participation in national service and volunteer programs is increasing, providing valuable opportunities for civic engagement. Volunteering and national service offer personal benefits, satisfaction, and opportunities for civic engagement and upward mobility. Established in the legislative branch is the Congressional Commission on Civic Service, also known as the Commission, with duties outlined for its role. The Congressional Commission on Civic Service, known as the Commission, aims to gather information and make recommendations to Congress to enhance national service and volunteerism in the United States. It focuses on improving individuals' ability to serve others, training leaders in public service organizations, addressing barriers to volunteering, and expanding volunteer opportunities. The Commission will analyze understanding of volunteer programs, issues deterring volunteerism, government roles in promoting service, and effectiveness of databases in matching community needs with volunteers. The Commission will analyze the impact of a mandatory national service requirement for all able young people, the potential for a public service academy, and how to strengthen the social fabric by bringing together people from diverse backgrounds. The Commission will analyze the impact of a mandatory national service requirement for all able young people, the potential for a public service academy, and how to strengthen the social fabric by bringing together people from diverse backgrounds. The focus is on training future public sector leaders, creating awareness of national service opportunities for students, establishing training programs on college campuses, expanding service opportunities abroad, and addressing constraints faced by service providers and agencies. The Commission will conduct public hearings and consult with an advisory panel of members of Congress to analyze federally funded volunteer programs and how to improve them to promote service among the "baby boomer" generation. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 8 members appointed by various leaders, with qualifications in international public service, national public service, service-learning, local service, business, or academia. The Commission shall consist of 8 members appointed with qualifications in international public service, national public service, service-learning, local service, business, or academia. The members shall serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member shall serve without pay, but will receive travel expenses. The deadline for appointment is 90 days after the enactment of this Act, and the Chairperson will be designated by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed with qualifications in various fields. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. Full-time federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. The Commission must meet quarterly and can have additional meetings as needed. Members of the Commission can meet using telephones or other suitable technologies as long as all members can communicate simultaneously. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson with approval of the Commission, who must have credentials related to public service. The Director's salary is determined by the Chairperson and cannot exceed the rate of basic pay for GS-15. The Director can appoint additional staff with approval and hire experts and consultants for temporary services. Upon request, Federal agencies may detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Staff rates should not exceed the daily equivalent of the maximum annual pay for GS-15. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold public hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. Departments must provide necessary information upon request. The Architect of the Capitol will provide facilities and equipment. Administrative support services can be requested. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Architect of the Capitol and the Administrator of General Services on a nonreimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Commission must submit an interim report to Congress within 20 months of the Act's enactment and a final report within 120 days of the interim report. The final report will include findings, conclusions, and legislative recommendations.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate within 30 days of submitting its final report.
